newsitem.title: USA: Florida executes killer of manufacturing heiress.
newsitem.headline: Florida executes killer of manufacturing heiress.

text.p: One of four men convicted for the 1982 convenience store murder of Evinrude heiress Frances Julia Slater was executed on Monday in Florida's electric chair, prison officials said.

John Earl Bush, 38, was pronounced dead at 7:09 p.m. EDT (2309 GMT) at Florida State Prison near Starke, Florida, according to Florida Department of Corrections spokesman Eugene Morris. The execution came a day after the U.S. Supreme Court refused to stop the death sentence originally scheduled to be carried out on Oct. 17.
Bush, dressed in blue pants and white shirt, made no comment before he died, Morris said. His last meal was steak, fried shrimp, baked potatoes, lemon pie and orange juice.

Bush was one of three men facing death for the April 27, 1982, robbery and murder of the 18-year-old Slater, granddaughter of Evinrude Motors Co. founder Ralph Evinrude. A fourth accomplice, Terry Wayne Johnson, was serving a life sentence.
Evinrude is a builder of motors for boats, snowmobiles and other recreational vehicles.
One of 368 death row inmates in Florida, Bush was the 37th to die in the state's electric chair since executions were resumed in 1979.
Parker, the trigger man, was also on death row. Cave, who was originally condemned to death, was awaiting resentencing due next month after his death sentence was overturned.
